# The Beatles' rooftop concert

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

The Beatles' rooftop concert [![The Beatles rooftop
concert.jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/d1/The_Beatles_rooftop_concert.jpg/240px-
The_Beatles_rooftop_concert.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_Beatles_rooftop_concert.jpg)

Venue | [Apple Corps Ltd](/wiki/Apple_Corps_Ltd "Apple Corps Ltd")  
3 Savile Row, London, UK

**The Beatles ' rooftop concert** was the final public performance of the
English [rock](/wiki/Rock_music "Rock music") band [the
Beatles](/wiki/The_Beatles "The Beatles"). On 30 January 1969, the band, with
keyboardist [Billy Preston](/wiki/Billy_Preston "Billy Preston"), surprised a
central London office and fashion district with an impromptu concert from the
roof of the headquarters of the band's multimedia corporation [Apple
Corps](/wiki/Apple_Corps "Apple Corps") at 3 [Savile Row](/wiki/Savile_Row
"Savile Row"). In a 42-minute set, the Beatles were heard playing nine takes
of five songs before the [Metropolitan Police
Service](/wiki/Metropolitan_Police_Service "Metropolitan Police Service")
asked them to reduce the volume. Footage from the performance was later used
in the 1970 documentary film _[Let It Be](/wiki/Let_It_Be_\(film\) "Let It Be
\(film\)")_.

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Beatles%27_rooftop_concert&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

Although the concert was unannounced, [the Beatles](/wiki/The_Beatles "The
Beatles") had planned on performing live during their _Get Back_ sessions
earlier in January.[2] It is uncertain who had the idea for a rooftop concert,
but the suggestion was conceived just days before the actual event.[3] [George
Harrison](/wiki/George_Harrison "George Harrison") brought in keyboardist
Billy Preston as an additional musician, in the hope that a talented outside
observer would encourage the band to be tight and focused.[3] [Ringo
Starr](/wiki/Ringo_Starr "Ringo Starr") remembered:

> "There was a plan to play live somewhere. We were wondering where we could
> go—'Oh, the Palladium or the Sahara'. But we would have had to take all the
> stuff, so we decided, 'Let's get up on the roof'".[4]

The audio was recorded onto two [eight-track
recorders](/wiki/Multitrack_recording "Multitrack recording") in the basement
of Apple[5] by engineer [Alan Parsons](/wiki/Alan_Parsons "Alan Parsons"),[6]
and film director [Michael Lindsay-Hogg](/wiki/Michael_Lindsay-Hogg "Michael
Lindsay-Hogg")[7] brought in a camera crew to capture several angles of the
performance—including reactions from people on the street.[6]

When the Beatles first started playing, there was some confusion from
spectators watching five stories below, many of whom were on their lunch
break. As the news of the event spread, crowds of onlookers began to
congregate in the streets and on the roofs of local buildings. While most
responded positively to the concert, the [Metropolitan Police
Service](/wiki/Metropolitan_Police_Service "Metropolitan Police Service") grew
concerned about noise and traffic issues.[8] [Apple](/wiki/Apple_Corps_Ltd
"Apple Corps Ltd") employees initially refused to let police inside,
ultimately reconsidering when threatened with arrest.[8]

As police ascended to the roof, the Beatles realised that the concert would
eventually be shut down, but continued to play for several more minutes.[9]
[Paul McCartney](/wiki/Paul_McCartney "Paul McCartney") improvised the lyrics
of his song "[Get Back](/wiki/Get_Back "Get Back")" to reflect the situation,
"You've been playing on the roofs again, and you know your Momma doesn't like
it, she's gonna have you arrested!"[10] The concert came to an end with the
conclusion of "Get Back", with [John Lennon](/wiki/John_Lennon "John Lennon")
saying, "I'd like to say thank you on behalf of the group and ourselves and I
hope we've passed the audition".[11]

## Set
list[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Beatles%27_rooftop_concert&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Set list")]

The rooftop concert consisted of nine takes of five Beatles songs, including:

  * "[Get Back](/wiki/Get_Back "Get Back")" (three takes)
  * "[Don't Let Me Down](/wiki/Don%27t_Let_Me_Down_\(Beatles_song\) "Don't Let Me Down \(Beatles song\)")" (two takes)
  * "[I've Got a Feeling](/wiki/I%27ve_Got_a_Feeling "I've Got a Feeling")" (two takes)
  * "[One After 909](/wiki/One_After_909 "One After 909")" (one take)
  * "[Dig a Pony](/wiki/Dig_a_Pony "Dig a Pony")" (one take)

The first performance of "I've Got a Feeling", and the recordings of "One
After 909", and "Dig a Pony" were later used for the album _Let It Be_.[12] In
1996, a "rooftop" version of "Get Back", which was the last song of the
Beatles' final live performance, was included in _[Anthology
3](/wiki/Anthology_3 "Anthology 3")_.[13] An edit of the two takes of "Don't
Let Me Down" was included on _[Let It Be... Naked](/wiki/Let_It_Be..._Naked
"Let It Be... Naked")._[14][_[better source needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS
"Wikipedia:NOTRS")_] There was also a brief jam of "I Want You (She's So
Heavy)" while the cameramen changed film.

##
Legacy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Beatles%27_rooftop_concert&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Legacy")]

---|---  
  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/3_Savile_Row.jpg/220px-3_Savile_Row.jpg)](/wiki/File:3_Savile_Row.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:3_Savile_Row.jpg "Enlarge")

3 Savile Row, London, the location of the concert

The Beatles' rooftop concert marked the end of an era for many fans. They did
record one more album, _[Abbey Road](/wiki/Abbey_Road "Abbey Road")_ , but by
September 1969 the Beatles had unofficially disbanded.[15] Several of the
rooftop performances, particularly that of "Dig a Pony", showed the Beatles
once again in top form, if only temporarily.[16] Fans believed the rooftop
concert might have been a try-out for a return to live performances and
touring.[17]

[The Rutles](/wiki/The_Rutles "The Rutles")' "Get Up and Go" sequence in the
film _[All You Need Is Cash](/wiki/All_You_Need_Is_Cash "All You Need Is
Cash")_ mimics the footage of the rooftop concert, and uses similar camera
angles.[18] In January 2009, tribute band [the Bootleg
Beatles](/wiki/The_Bootleg_Beatles "The Bootleg Beatles") attempted to stage a
40th anniversary concert in the same location, but were refused permission by
[Westminster City Council](/wiki/Westminster_City_Council "Westminster City
Council") due to licensing problems.[19]

In _[The Simpsons](/wiki/The_Simpsons "The Simpsons")_ [fifth
season](/wiki/The_Simpsons_\(season_5\) "The Simpsons \(season 5\)") episode
"[Homer's Barbershop Quartet](/wiki/Homer%27s_Barbershop_Quartet "Homer's
Barbershop Quartet")", the Be Sharps ([Homer](/wiki/Homer_Simpson "Homer
Simpson"), [Apu](/wiki/Apu_Nahasapeemapetilon "Apu Nahasapeemapetilon"),
[Barney](/wiki/Barney_Gumble "Barney Gumble") and [Principal
Skinner](/wiki/Seymour_Skinner "Seymour Skinner")) perform a rendition of one
of their previous hits on a rooftop. [George Harrison](/wiki/George_Harrison
"George Harrison"), who guest-starred in the episode, is shown saying
dismissively "It's been done!" As the song ends and the credits begin, Homer
repeats John Lennon's phrase about passing the audition and everyone laughs,
including Barney until he says, "I don't get it."[20]

In the 2007 film _[Across The Universe](/wiki/Across_the_Universe_\(film\)
"Across the Universe \(film\)")_ , a musical made up entirely of Beatles'
music, Sadie's band performs a rooftop concert in New York City which mimics
the original. It is interrupted and closed down by the New York Police
Department.[21]

[U2](/wiki/U2 "U2") also referenced the concert in their video for "[Where the
Streets Have No Name](/wiki/Where_the_Streets_Have_No_Name "Where the Streets
Have No Name")", which featured a similar rooftop concert in [Los
Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles").

McCartney played a surprise mini-concert in midtown Manhattan on 15 July 2009
from the top of the marquee of the [Ed Sullivan
Theater](/wiki/Ed_Sullivan_Theater "Ed Sullivan Theater"), where he was
recording a performance for _[Late Show with David
Letterman](/wiki/Late_Show_with_David_Letterman "Late Show with David
Letterman")_. News of the event spread via [Twitter](/wiki/Twitter "Twitter")
and word of mouth, and nearby street corners were closed off to accommodate
fans for the set, which duplicated the original Beatles gig.

qa.question: where did the beatles final live performance take place
qa.answer: ["the roof of the headquarters of the band's multimedia corporation Apple Corps at 3 Savile Row"]
